title: Tuesday, 7th May 2019
bodyHTML:
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Hello.

VV75 morning
nightingale20201 morning all
BE11:08am

Never gets easier, does it? Good morning welcome, hi. Markets Live, FT Alphaville's saergsdgr sadfsdfbh.

JP11:08am

Morning all.

DRichi Good morning
Are we there yet Hi there
11:08 am
JP11:09am

Slow start today after a weekend trip to Tel-Aviv.

JP11:09am

Hope ROTR managed to get some r'n'r in also.

Soundbuy Morning
cracklenpop Guten Tag. Purplebricks, bitte
Are we there yet Mother of God
BE11:10am

I, meanwhile, couldn't give a stuff about the ROTR's r'n'r.

11:10 am
JP11:10am

BE -- you'll be pleased to hear that I met one avid ML reader at the wedding I was attending. Not sure what was wrong with him, didn't chat to them long enough to ascertain.

BE11:11am

That'll be 10 per cent of the audience right there.

BE11:11am

Hey, remember I mentioned a while back I was clearing junk out of my desk pre office move?

Grouchmonkey Morning all
11:11 am
JP11:11am

What have you discovered now?

BE11:11am

Here's a thing I found on Friday.

BE11:12am

Soundbuy That'll be the loner in the kitchen.......
11:11 am
BE11:12am

That there is a pitchbook from 2008 or so.

BE11:12am

About a take-private of "Timor"

VV75 someone is selling Playtech, wasn't there a rumour of some sorts a couple weeks ago?
JP11:13am

Look at that company structure.

11:12 am
JP11:13am

Rallye-esque.

JP11:13am

(@Soundbuy -- yep.)

BE11:13am

There's a lot to enjoy here, not least it's a PE pitch put together by Kaupthing.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

TO BE EXTREMELY CLEAR, IT'S A VERY VERY OLD DOCUMENT.

BE11:14am

Like, a decade.

BE11:14am

And I don't think we even wrote a story on it, in the end.

11:14 am
JP11:15am

My desk clear out is mainly getting rid of Kadhim's abandoned treasures.

BE11:15am

Yikes.

PBateman hello all
BE11:15am

Anyway, we should bump on to the stocks portion of the day.

Zeffos Hi all!
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Starting with .......................

undefined
JP11:15am

A year old bottle of Tropicana.

11:15 am
JP11:16am

Blacker than the night now.

BE11:16am

.... we could start with a year old bottle of Tropicana, but maybe Purplebricks would be a like-for-like equivalent.

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 128.00, down 7 (-5.19%), High: 130.60, Low: 120.80, Volume: 765.37k
11:16 am
JP11:16am

Teeth smile

BE11:16am

So .............. founder's out.

Grouchmonkey Which would you rather be - Neil Woodford or Theresa May?
BE11:17am

Michael Bruce -- widely referred to as the founder, but didn't his brother also have a role here? -- gone, to be replaced by Vic Darvey

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The guy they only just hired from Moneysupermarket.

MnM Howdy
BE11:17am

As well as that you have an exit from Australia

BE11:18am

And a slow exit from the US

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Leaving the UK (and Canada, though no one seems sure why Canada)

JP11:18am

Australia's property market has been pretty juiced for a while now.

red the q is will NW be doubling.tripling/quadrupling down today lol
JP11:18am

Same as Canada's.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

And yet Purplebricks made a right mess of Australia

red @Grouchmonkeyi would ask for rope
BE11:19am

The statement concedes they made mistakes. Correctly.

BE11:19am

Now, there are a couple of things to note here beyond the tearing up the strategy stuff.

red there are reasons why purps model hasnt been working in aus and the us
11:19 am
JP11:20am

Do go on.

BE11:20am

The first is that Mr Bruce has an 11% shareholding.

JP11:20am

And Woodford has 29.62%.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

Well, yes, which of course means he couldn't absorb that 11% even if he wanted to.

BE11:21am

In terms of willing buyers you're looking downwards to Axel Springer.

VV75 what is his highest paid price of the last 12 months?
BE11:21am

Third biggest with ...... 12% ish, I think, by memory.

11:21 am
JP11:21am

12.45%

red i wonder if he will try to do another provident on shareholders
BE11:22am

Thumbs up

BE11:22am

Now, the other part of this is whether cutting the lossmaking businesses will mean Purplebricks can avoid another cash call.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

And ............ maybe, But it's still going to be pretty tight, particularly as you now have a business that's extremely dependent on the UK market.

JP11:23am

We haven't had a balance sheet since Oct 31, but the cash position then was £103.1m.

kemche Would Axel wish to go from singed fingers to incinerated?
BE11:23am

And all its peers -- let's face it they're peers, even if they have agents on the payroll rather than gig economy -- are trading at death-knell levels.

11:23 am
Foxtons Group PLC (FOXT:LSE): Last: 65.90, up 1.4 (+2.17%), High: 66.00, Low: 65.50, Volume: 5.72k
Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 6.18, up 0.1688 (+2.81%), High: 6.18, Low: 5.86, Volume: 234.69k
wayneJ What is interesting with the PurpleBricks statement is (1) 'immediate effect' for Michael Bruce to step down (2) No comment from Michael Bruce in the statement.
BE11:24am

Let be cut to some UBS.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Our valuation of 100p values the UK at an EV of £260m (62p per share), the US at an EV of £30m assuming break-even in 2025E and Australia at an EV of £7m. In an upside scenario, we value Purplebricks at 300p vs 55p in a downside scenario. For us to consider turning positive on the name, we would need to see further evidence that no more funding to grow the US business is needed; losses in the US to improve post FY19; an acceleration in market share gains in the UK and faster operating leverage. A final announcement on the US strategic review should provide more clarity on potential requirements for further funding and the level of losses in the US in the medium term.

JP11:25am

Quite a wide band there...55p to 330p.

JP11:25am

That's one way of framing execution risk.

kemche But Michael is thanked by the Chairman, straight faced, which is nice.
11:25 am
JP11:25am

Sorry, 300p. Fat finger.

Montesquieu Decisive action by the Chairman, an unusual false step by Matthias Dopfner at Axel Springer. More bumps in the road ahead.
red not sure the model is right for the US. in fact i believe it to be wrong. its a place where folks open talk around the dinner table how much they made last year.
BE11:26am

Yep. Worth highlighting that in today's statement Purplebricks has 2019 cash balances of not less than £62m. Which is where the consensus already was, so I'm not sure where the rundown costs here are going to fall.

BE11:26am

Citi:

anonymous254 @red, what are they? Are they US/AU specific?
11:27 am
BE11:27am

We understand that the [CEO] decision reflects the evolution of the business which requires a new set of skills in its next phase. Vic brings significant online technology businesses experience, including holding the position of Managing Director at MoneySupermarket.

BE11:27am

It reflects the evolution of the business? Righty ho.

BE11:27am

Recent announcements hint at a significant decision to focus its investment to reserve cash. The exit of Australia and the significant scale back of US investment (as previously announced) will support a significantly lower cash burn than we have modelled prior to the recent strategic announcements

11:27 am
BE11:28am

It's amazing how efficiently they can suck the life out of drama .....

BE11:28am

I mean, it's a boardroom carpet knifing.

BE11:28am

Significant news flow, however, we wait for further details on 3 July
2019 to revisit our long term investment thesis. Strategic decisions to date, including the exit of Australia and the scale down in the US, will support cash flow and likely bring forward a potential group financial breakeven date. The delivery of FY19e revenue guidance will be viewed positively given the recent market negativity and weaker market volumes, particularly in the UK and Australia

11:28 am
JP11:29am

And here's Peel Hunt for good measure:

JP11:29am

Trading and revenues for the full year are in line with previous guidance, but the group has taken action to exit the Australian business while the US business is also under strategic review. The profitable UK operations and Canadian business look set to be the core of the group. Board changes see Michael Bruce leave the business and he will be replaced as CEO by Vic Darvey, who joined the group as COO from Moneysupermarket earlier this year. Our forecasts and recommendation remain under review until there is more clarity on the structure of the business and a further strategy update is provided by the Board. Final results are due for release on 3rdJuly.

JP11:29am

No one has a clue.

11:29 am
JP11:30am

Got to say, the heavily subsidised US housing market should be bread and butter for a disruptive business model like PURP. But I digress.

BE11:30am

There's disruptive and there's having a business model that's fundamentally flawed, tho.

BE11:30am

Though perhaps they're one in the same, come to think of it.

11:30 am
undefined
VV75 some media are citing city insiders quoting the Metro Bank rights issue at between 400-450p
BE11:31am

Okay, where next? We weren't around yesterday for trade waffle.

red @anonymous254us is bottom line results focused. thats how the folks there are. they are suspicious of front loaded methods. as they are in aus.
JP11:31am

On the same theme, Uber's IPO is this week.

VV75 did they not raise 300mio at 3400 last year or something?
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Oh yes, that's exciting sort of.

Joesph H Zoap. More good news from GWP yesterday.
JP11:32am

Another in the grand novel of business of models of tomorrow that don't make money today.

Tom Dalgleish very generous of PURP to tackle the Oz market during a steep downturn
JP11:32am

Right, what else?

Irish Credit Can I ask about Thomas Cook again - press speculation about Lufthansa bidding for Condor segment - Any broker comment on competition issue given the Air Berlin restrictions
Mr Ticker Any Tate & Lyle grey again BE please?
11:33 am
BE11:33am

I guess we could wrap up the weekend press, having not done so yesterday.

Flaneur Half way through and no mention of the New Arrival. Very slack Bryce.BBC had it at the top of their website for most of the weekend.... dontchaknow
JP11:34am

Something about a Trump tweet?

JP11:34am

I wasn't paying attention.

Kiwi-juice hello@BE: are you getting any strategy notes on what to do with the Trade War back on the agenda?
cracklenpop AJ Bell hitting new highs again - shares have almost trebled in 6 months after IPO
Flaneur (@JP - Donald or Judd?)
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Oh, the trade stuff? Likewise, I wasn't either.

BE11:35am

My attention in terms of the Sundays was caught by this kind of thing.

BE11:35am

REVERED Wall Street activist Elliott Advisors is poised to renew its attack on Whitbread, putting it on a collision course with boss Alison Brittain for the second time in little over a year.

The Sunday Telegraph understands that Elliott is becoming increasingly frustrated by the leisure giant's strategy of owning Premier Inn hotels outright, claiming that such a move is depressing the company's share price and leaving it open to a cut-price hostile takeover.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

That's the SunTel.

Lemmy Irish Credit: it's not just speculation, CEO said it at the AGM today
red @Kiwi-juicethe trick i learned was to look at what has done very well most recently and do the opposite.
BE11:36am

And I'm sure Elliott is terrified of the idea that a donkey that it backed would be the subject of a hostile.

BE11:36am

https://www.telegr...-radical-overhaul/

11:36 am
JP11:36am

So what's the alternative -- sale and leaseback?

JP11:36am

License model?

BE11:36am

The Elliott plan at Whitbread was mostly just Costa, I suspect.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Post that, who knows? I guess wait for the cash return and agitate for sales of pubs. Don't think anyone's talked sale and leaseback yet.

red the will be most likely st and to the detriment of the lt health of the company
wayneJ @JP - Whitbread presentation makes clear that controlling the underlying assets are important for their business model. They lease circa 1/3 of the hotels and own the rest. Emphasise that need to control the entire value chain.
wayneJ I would proffer that anyone who thinks sale and leaseback is a good thing ought to consider Southern Cross.
JP11:38am

Premier Inn near my place West could do with a spring spruce.

red for S&L they need only look to the retailers and it turned out for them
JP11:38am

If you're reading Mr Singer.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Though of course, Elliott is a long-term value investors who wouldn't want a hostile bid to undermine the value argument that ..... no, sorry, it's an opportunist vampire. my mistake.

JP11:38am

Omg smileOmg smileOmg smile

BE11:38am

Otherwise .... Metro ......

11:38 am
Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 627.50, down 11 (-1.72%), High: 638.00, Low: 617.50, Volume: 174.05k
GBKrona @WayneJ - surely licensee model a la IHG is better for new sites - higher ROCE, ROE
Irish Credit Struggle to see how EU would allow Lufthansa buy Condor given Condor's slots at Dussledorf airport and that was one of the reason Lufthansa was prevented from bidding on Air Berlin subsidiary.
BE11:40am

Was it the Times saying 400-450p?

BE11:41am

Which .... is a wee bit obvious? No? You price share issues at a 30% discount or thereabouts?

11:41 am
BE11:41am

So, not a lot to add there either.

wayneJ @GBK - the issue is that part of the brand value is being able to control the whole business. Remember you are charging as low as £19 per night.
undefined
BE11:42am

Okay, turning back to requests ..........

11:42 am
Tate & Lyle PLC (TATE:LSE): Last: 765.40, down 2.2 (-0.29%), High: 774.40, Low: 762.80, Volume: 393.88k
BE11:42am

Nothing whatsoever to add to what was said last week, to be clear.

JP11:42am

(@WayneJ -- that makes sense. I guess it's harder to monitor how the brand is faring from a far, vis-a-vis a higher end chain where the signals are stronger.)

11:42 am
BE11:43am

.... And no reason to wind back on it either.

wayneJ @GBK - also worth remembering that some of the profit for the co. is from developing sites, maturing them and then selling and leasing back so it is already in the numbers. As an investor - I would suggest it is worth adding what you think the property valuation uplift is to the numbers. Also worth remembering that IFRS will force co.s to acknowledge lease liability.
BE11:43am

FeltcollaredsourceThumbs up

BE11:43am

Martin Deboo of Jefferies has some thoughts though.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Deboo's very good.

BE11:44am

Though might be better to read us directly than read the Bloomberg summaries.

BE11:44am

The shares touched 800p last week on speculation in the Financial
Times (FT) that Roquette had made a 900p per share offer.

GBKrona @WayneJ - true about property profits (in a market where property prices are rising) - but that can hold back expansion. Licensee model actual helps reduce costs - look at McDonalds, Coke (distribution), etc.
11:44 am
BE11:45am

Nope, we didn't say that. We said Roquette had approached Tate to talk about a combination with a price range somewhere towards 900p, though possibly a bit below.

BE11:45am

Nuance is important here.

BE11:45am

We can't rule it out, but think it unlikely. More plausible for us is that Roquette might be interested in some of Tate's primary processing assets in the US, a scenario we have been mulling for a while.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Tate CEO Nick Hampton was talking up acquisitions in the FT
last week. But high multiples for ingredient assets mean that affordable deals are less than transformational, even at his putative greater than 2x ND:EBITDA. Recycling capital out of Primary could therefore be a game-changer. But the hurdles are high ones.

BE11:46am

Tricky but not impossible to exit a facility, with Decatur the most viable option for us. Exiting selectively Primary in the US is the strategic equivalent of microsurgery, given tight integration of Speciality & Bulk processing and the impact on overall scale. Our most favoured option, based on a detailed review, would be to exit Decatur, Tate's biggest US facility, which is heavily skewed towards HFCS 42 & industrial starch. A solution would however need to be found for polydextrose and soluble fibre, both mission-critical.

GBKrona also WayneJ I am not advocating sale & leaseback for existing properties necessarily - just a licensee model for new properties / new markets (e.g. Germany, rest of EU)
BE11:46am

Would hasten the journey to Speciality, no question. The devil is in the dilution, and the timing. Exiting Decatur and recycling the proceeds into deals could shift Tate to c.60% of profits from Speciality, relative to 45% now. But only at the cost of well into doubledigit EPS dilution, which would require a PER of up to 18x to maintain the current share price. This in the context of previous dilutive exits never really being rewarded. It also implies selling corn wet milling assets late in the cycle, when even ADM are shifting out of HFCS 42.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Which is all plausible, I guess, but it's not what we understand to have happened.

Mr Ticker Cheers BE
wayneJ @GBK - not violently disagreeing - but I note Diageo does not license (at least not to the Coca Cola extent).
Tom Dalgleish 54/100
BE11:48am

Which, to reiterate, involves Roquette very recently pitching a combination at a premium with backing from various parties.

JP11:48am

Thumbs up

11:48 am
BE11:48am

But apparently there's nothing needed said to you, the investor. So ........

undefined
wayneJ @GBK - the ROCE on hotels for Premier Inn is circa 12- 14% which ain't bad - but I highly recommend reading the co. slides.
BE11:49am

What next?

11:49 am
JP11:49am

One company that's in that rare basket of UK businesses that do well and no one talks about...

BE11:49am

Is it FT Group?

JP11:49am

Apart from them, obviously.

11:49 am
4imprint Group PLC (FOUR:LSE): Last: 2,610, up 30 (+1.16%), High: 2,700, Low: 2,580, Volume: 8.67k
BE11:50am

Go on.

VV75 who?
JP11:50am

Makers of marketing widgets that get handed out at trade fairs and the like. Business is pretty much all US, but trades like a UK stock.

chopper bear begbies Traynor seems to fall into that also :-)
11:50 am
JP11:50am

So one to watch if Brexit manages to get any worse.

A. M. Purveyor of tchotchkes.
GBKrona @WayneJ - most of Diageo's distribution is indeed done by third parties - so partly licensed. Their volumes are a small fraction for Coke's, the margins that much higher, and provenance is high for credibility - which is why they do not license bottling in the main. I know their model quite well - spent over a decade with them.
JP11:51am

Anyway, trading update today. Revenue growth up 16 per cent for the first four months. Thanks to a product mix towards slightly higher ticket items.

VV75 do they make widgets they hand out at elections?
Istrain @BE - wasn't it one of Bramson's first activist forays? shows what he could have done at barclays...
JP11:52am

Here's Peel Hunt:

11:52 am
JP11:52am

Trading detail: In the first four months order volumes are up 14% and revenue up 16%. The average order size is currently benefitting from a rising element of apparel sales, which generally are made at higher price points so building overall order values. In the comparable period in FY18 the company enjoyed 16% revenue growth, but with the brand TV spend having an impact for part of the period (mid-March onwards).

JP11:52am

(@VV75, yes.)

JP11:52am

More:

11:52 am
JP11:52am

Implication for forecasts: We are looking for full-year growth in North America of 12%, below the rate seen in the average of the first 4 months. To hit this requires growth – broadly – in the remaining period of 10%. The comparable months in 2018 were all strong months driven by the TV brand building campaign. It is logical to expect growth in the remaining period may be lower than the 16%. At this stage we are not minded to change forecasts, noting the outlook comment from the company. We therefore make no change to forecast at this stage but recognise this is a firm foundation for existing forecasts.

JP11:53am

Valuation: The shares have rallied hard since the start of the year, rising from 1,900p to 2,670p. This performance has closed a valuation gap that was unwarranted and based initially on market ambivalence towards the increased marketing spend, and more recently on US growth fears.

VV75 awfully thin order book in the stock itself though
wayneJ @GBK - stand corrected!
JP11:54am

And Liberum, who are a touch more cautious:

11:54 am
JP11:54am

4imprint’s AGM trading statement for the first four months of 2019 guides to trading in line with expectations. Revenue has grown 16% in the first four months of 2019, ahead of expected growth for the year of 13.2%. Comps were easy as the brand awareness program was launched in March 2018, but become harder. We leave our total EBIT margin unchanged at 6.3%, slightly up from 6.1% in FY18. We also leave our FY19 FD EPS estimate unchanged at 149.5c, a 16% increase on the prior year. We expect DPS, which is determined in US$ but paid in Sterling, to increase in line with the increase in EPS of 16% YoY to 80.9c. Sterling is currently 1.31 ($/£) and remains broadly unchanged against the dollar since the 2018 year-end when it was 1.28. 4imprint is in a strong position to meet its strategic goal of $1bn of sales by 2022. Interims are on 31st July. We expect an H1 weighting of 47% for sales and 35% for EBIT given the seasonality of marketing, giving an expected H1 FD EPS of 52.6c.

JP11:54am

We maintain our FY 2019 net cash estimate of $37.8m, vs $37.5m in FY 2018. We continue to expect net capex to increase from £2.9m in FY 2018 to £8.5m, due to the additional $5m investment in Oshkosh, the Wisconsin distribution centre. The $5m investment in Oshkosh will add 80k sq ft of capacity, taking the total to 300k sq ft. This will help to grow the Apparel business, since embroidery is done in-house and helps to deliver good service levels, which are key. As the cash pile grows, this gives management options for further shareholder distributions, perhaps via another special dividend like the one we saw at the FY 2017 results for 60c. However, we expect the board would like to maintain a cash buffer to ensure that the business can take advantage of any market weakness.

JP11:55am

Anyway, thought it was worth flagging. A relative bright spot in UK companies, given the rest of the market action we seem to talk about on here.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

I've a feeling Barclays is pushing them this morning,

JP11:55am

Oh yeah?

BE11:55am

Hang on, let me check ......

wayneJ @GBK - hope my general point stands - that licensing can introduce friction and for a very low margin / high utilisation business can impact profits.
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Yep! James Zaremba.

BE11:55am

4imprint, a direct marketer of promotional products, has therare combination of a LT track record of earnings growth (18% 10yr EBIT CAGR) delivered with very high ROCE(greater than 80%) and a clear runway for this to continue given it still has only 2.5% marketshare despite being the #1 player. We initiate at OW with a £45PT.

BE11:56am

8 factors, for us,make this an attractive business:

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Eight!

JP11:56am

Woah. £45? That's 100% from here.

BE11:56am

1) Acapital-light direct marketing model–the group’s suppliers are responsible for production and inventory; 2) Aleading customer proposition–earnings are driven by attracting more customers to a market-leading proposition which we view aseminently more sustainable than earnings driven by squeezing the customer; 3) Areturns-focused approach to growth–management apply a rigorous approach to capital allocation,only investing when a return can be measured and is high; 4) Playing in the right parts of the market–management only target customers with high lifetime values. These are customers who care about service, are very sticky when served well and buy directrather than via a procurement function; 5) Attractive economics for retaining target customers–it is much cheaper to retain than acquire customers,therefore as a new customer becomes retained marketing budget is freed up to further grow the customer base;6) Attractive economics for higher volumes–the group gets better terms on price, delivery speed and other areas with suppliers as a result of providing them with the largest volumesreinforcing the customer proposition;7) Afragmented marketplace–in spite of being market leader by some marginthe group only has a 2.5% market share; and8) A long-term approach to business–this is evident in several areas and is supportive of more enduring growth

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Yeah, eight factors though. That's only 12.5% a factor.

JP11:56am

True.

BE11:57am

Assuming you don't compound them.

A. M. "the group’s suppliers are responsible for production and inventory" -- does that mean that they source their stuff from China?
11:57 am
JP11:57am

Anyway, a good one of those looking to get away from assets exposed to the UK, and don't want to invest in companies who extract stuff out the ground.

JP11:57am

97% US revenues I believe.

undefined
11:57 am
JP11:57am

(@A.M. -- not sure.)

BE11:58am

What else we got to round up with?

A. M. (@JP: thanks)
BE11:58am

There's a big Stifel note that seems to have hit the distributors.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Though it mostly says "things are fine but might get worse" so I'm not sure why it's been taken so hard.

DCC PLC (DCC:LSE): Last: 6,618, down 216 (-3.16%), High: 6,792, Low: 6,618, Volume: 67.25k
Essentra PLC (ESNT:LSE): Last: 391.45, down 26.35 (-6.31%), High: 411.80, Low: 386.80, Volume: 768.59k
11:59 am
Electrocomponents PLC (ECM:LSE): Last: 623.00, down 18.6 (-2.90%), High: 630.60, Low: 614.60, Volume: 273.23k
BE11:59am

Etc.

BE12:00pm

The Industrial Distribution sub-set of our coverage universe includes seven stocks: Bunzl,
DCC, Diploma, DiscoverIE, Electrocomponents, Essentra and Ferguson. In this note,
we introduce a less aggressive view of the sustainability and robustness of economic
prospects. We expect share price risk to remain exaggerated as the market continues to
be trigger happy to first circumstantial evidence of cyclical risks. With valuations already
high across the space, this leaves little room for any execution mishaps and limited scope
for material re-rating but plenty for material de-rating. We downgrade to Hold on Bunzl,
DCC, DiscoverIE, Electrocomponents, Essentra and Ferguson and retain our Hold on
Diploma.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Sorry about the lumpy line formatting.

BE12:00pm

Big picture considerations. We take a less aggressive view of the sustainability
and robustness of economic prospects. The cycle is long in the tooth but we expect
supportive end-markets throughout 2H19 even as we expect a transition to a lower growth
environment. Beyond that, the picture is more uncertain. The corollary of a more cautious
stance, and lack of confidence in our estimates post the year ahead, is a higher risk
premium applied to our DCF valuations.
We expect share price risk to remain exaggerated as the market continues to be 'trigger
happy' to first circumstantial evidence of cyclical risks. In other words, with high valuations
across our Industrial Distribution group, there is little room for error in risk-volatile equity
markets – Bunzl's recent 1Q update and share price fall of 9% on the day is a case in point.
Across the group, visibility is limited beyond trend extension, there is little asset backing
to support views of potential in more challenging times and dividend yields are low.

BE12:01pm

Moderating organic growth, concern about Amazon's move into wholesaling unlikely to go away, M&A pipelines looking less of a feature .....

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

So stay cautious into the June updates. That's the gist.

undefined
BE12:02pm

Okay, we done? Can't think of much else to do.

12:02 pm
JP12:02pm

Yep.

OnYourRight Thanks BE/JP/Rotr
JP12:03pm
